title: Open Data Science
body:
Data science combines advanced data literacy and statistical knowledge with domain expertise. This combination of skills helps derive valuable insights and communicate them to others.

This one-day course gives you practical knowledge in open data science and the skills you need to develop in the area.

title: Course overview
body: The course is split into four main sessions. These sessions start by exploring the current role of a data scientist and the key skills and competencies required. Each preceding session then takes a practical look at applying a number of these competencies.

_items.title: Introducing open data science
_items.body:
What is Open Data Science?

This session explores the concepts, key competencies and modern characteristics of an Open Data Scientist.

_items.alt: Big data, data collection and analysis
_items.title: Big data, data collection and analysis
_items.body:
One of the core skills of a modern data scientist is to reliably collect, manage and quickly analyse data of all sizes and types.

This session looks at the key tools that can help gather and analyse some of the many data types and sizes out there.

We start by visulising 6 million rows of data in under 5 minutes.

_items.title: Maths, machine learning and prediction
_items.body:
Data flows are constant, but can we predict what the next outcome will be?

This session looks at using machine learning to classify large amounts of data using a statistical analysis tool.

_items.title: Visualising and presenting data
_items.body:
Communicating insight from data is now an essential skill of a modern data scientist.

This session takes a practical look at producing advanced infographics on the web.

title: Introducing open data science
body: This session explores the concepts, key competencies and modern characteristics of an Open Data Scientist.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Profile of a data scientist
_items.body:
Drew Conways venn diagram of a data scientist (shown left) offers a good insight into the key skills and profile of a data scientist.

Expanding on this using modern profiling techniques it is possible to summarise the key competencies of a data scientist into eight main areas:

  • Big data
  • Machine learning and prediction
  • Data collection and analysis
  • Maths and statistics
  • Interpretation and visualisation
  • Advanced computing and programming
  • Business intelligence and domain expertise
  • Open source tools and concepts
_items.strapline: Core skills of a modern data scientist

_items.title: Essential skills
_items.body:
In order to find out which skills are most important for a modern data scientist the European Data Science Academy project (EDSA) interviewed 633 people and asked them to rate the importance of each of the 8 key skills areas.

The result here shows that Data collection and analysis is the most essential skill by some margin. This along with the next four skills, form the basis for this course.

_graphic.alt: Essential skills for a data scientist
_graphic.title: Essential skills for a data scientist

_items.strapline: Essential skills for a data scientist

_items.title: The current skills landscape
_items.body:
The EDSA project also asked 355 people who self classify themselves as data scientists which skills they are strong in.

This shows a marked difference from the requirement, with data collection and analysis being one of the weakest skills, compared to interpretation and visualisation.
_items.strapline: The current data science skills landscape

title: Big data, data collection and analysis
displayTitle: Big data, data collection and analysis

title: Big data
body:
The ability to manage large scale data that is constantly changing requires new ways of managing data. Desktop machines running Excel are simply not capable of easily scaling to handle massive quantities of data.

To process big data requires the use of flexible and scalable infrastructure that can be accessed and used on demand. Helpfully companies like Amazon and Microsoft provide cloud infrastructure that provides exactly this.

Explore the exercise below which demonstrates how Socrata is providing open data platforms that allow huge amounts of data to be processed simply and without the need for downloading it first.

Try out this to see how easy it can be to manage and process big data.

title: Unlocking data on the web
body: The first challenge with an data science project is to prepare your data. Some data you might already have, but this might be incomplete or need enriching with other data this is available on the web. Unfortunately, not all data is easy to get hold of. This session unlocks the secrets of obtaining and preparing data that is available on the web.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: Downloadable data
_items.body:
Many suppliers are helpful and give you human readable download links in order to obtain their data.

Explore the links below to discover more:

  • data.gov.uk - Land Registry Monthly Property Transaction Data
  • Nike - Manufacturing Map
  • New York City Open Data

_items.title: Power search for data
_items.body:
Many search engines, including google, give you the ability to use advanced searches and prefixs in order to dig out data.

Try some of the following search prefixes in google to see what you can find:

filetype:

Search for specific file types only, e.g. (xls) (example)

site:

Search with a specific domain or site only (example)

related:

Search for content related to a known page (example)

link:

List only pages that link to the one given (example)

_items.title: Aggregators and portals
_items.body:
Aggregates and portals bring together data from accross the web and expose through their own service. This creates and easy and consistant way to find and download data.

Explore the links below to find out more:

enigma.io

Powerful open data searching for structured data

Transport API

All UK transport data, in one place, with one API.

_items.title: Web scraping
_items.body:
If you can't simply download data in a usable format, you may need to scrape it. Helpfully there are now many tools that help us achieve this easily:

pdftables.com

Upload a PDF, download data, simple.

magic.import.io

Extract data from web pages in a click.

title: Unlocking data in the web
body: A lot of data is not available via searches or download buttons. To unlock this data we have to think more like a computer.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data from in the web.

_items.title: Adding extensions
_items.body:
Some web pages are also data resources in themselves. In these cases you can try adding data file extensions (e.g. csv, json, xml, rdf etc) to the web address in order to access structured data.

Try some of the examples below to see what you find:

All gov.uk data

Add '.json' to any page of gov.uk (e.g. the UK Trade Tariff data).

BBC Programme pages

Add '.xml' or '.rdf' to any BBC programme page (e.g. Doctor Who).

_items.title: Finding alternative links
_items.body:
Some websites offer data feeds in the form of RSS feeds or email subscriptions. Such services provide timely updates of new information and can be reused by many applications.

The following a good examples of data feeds that are available:

  • BBC News Feeds
  • Met Office Weather feeds

_items.title: Extracting embedded data
_items.body:
Many websites dynamically load data, saving web browsers time loading endless pages. This is especially the case with embedded weather widgets and shopping websites where templates are filled with data once they are loaded.

As a nice aside, this means that your web browser has loaded structured data onto your computer. All we have to do is access it directly so it can be used.

Try out the hidden data extractor and see what you can find hiding in existing web pages.

_items.title: Content negotiation
_items.body:
Content negotiation is the machine equivalent of adding file extensions to ask for different formats.

Rather than add extensions, machines can provide a list of priorities for formats they would like and negotiate with the server to get these.

You can find out more about content negotiation from Wikipedia.

_items.title: Using APIs
_items.body:
Application Programme Interfaces (APIs) are machine interfaces designed for specific services.

They are most often designed to allow applications to query data and in some cases make changes to the data.

In many cases an API is simply a pattern of web addresses (URLs) that can be adjusted to perform different actions.

Examples of APIs in action include:

  • Flickr
  • OpenCorporates
  • Transport API

title: Machine learning and classification
body:
Machine learning is all about the construction and study of systems that can learn from data.

There are many techniques that can be used with data, however one of the most common techniques is classification.

When classifying data, you first train the machine with a training set, and then test effectiveness are error margin with a test set. This can then lead to automated ways of classifying new data.

Classification techniques are commonly used with facial recognition, email spam filters and fraud detection.

In this section we are going to look at classifying a dataset of houses.

Download the houses dataset

title: Exploring R
body:
R is statistical programming language. It can rapidly speed up the process of freely and flexibly exploring and discovering insight from a dataset.

Additional libraries also provide automated mechanisms for building machine learning algorithms and classifiers.

This exercise takes you through the process of exploring R with our dataset

Open R Studio Online to get started with this exercise (requires registration).

title: Exploring data through visualisation
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Exploring space
_items.body:
The Universe is vast and on a scale people just simply cannot grasp.

Visualising this effectively is key to increase understanding of our place in the Universe.

_items.title: Faster transport?
_items.body:
Visualising data can quickly tell us stories of progress.

The example on the left became part of the advertising campaign for SNCF. It was used to communicate how much faster the new TGV trains were.

_items.title: Light cycles
_items.body:
Improving mobility is key to the future of successful and smart cities.

Visualising usage of transport systems (in this case bicycles in London) can help make key decisions about future planning of such systems.

Click here to watch the full video.

_items.title: In flight
_items.body:
Transport problems are not just limited to single cities. There is a lot we can learn from analysing global transport patterns.

This example looks at the evolution of flight and uses advanced visualision to tell a story about the history of flight. Using a bit of machine learning, it even attempts to predict the future.

Click here to explore In Flight

title: Exploring complex datasets
body:
Visualisations can help us explore a dataset to unlock insight.

In particular faceted browsing (or cross filters) allow consumers to filter the data visually. Such browsers are commonly now used by holiday and flight websites, such as Sky scanner to help you filter your search results or change input parameters.

Try out this exercise to build your own cross filter with the housing data from earlier

You will need this link to start the exercise.

title: Open Data Science
body:
Data science combines advanced data literacy and statistical knowledge with domain expertise. This combination of skills helps derive valuable insights and communicate them to others.

In this course we explored some of the key specialisms of a data scientist, in particular 'data skills', 'machine learning' and 'visualisation'.

The houses dataset provided a solid base for demonstrate and I must thank those behind r2d3.us for putting this excellent data science demo together.

Looking to the future, more data will increase the need to be able to filter it. Perhaps one day we shall all be using tools like Pivot.
